The Susquenita School Board approved electronic excuses for absences and tardiness. The District has developed an electronic form for you to use when you need to write an excuse for your child. As with written excuses, the electronic form needs to be submitted within three school days of the student’s absence to excuse your child due to illness. You may still send in a hand written note or you can use the electronic form for your convenience. Please note, if you do have a medical excuse, you will need to email a copy of it, drop it off at the office, or send it by USPS mail to the building your child attends.

The excuse for absences and tardiness can be used for all students regardless if they are hybrid, remote, cyber, or face to face.

The link can be found on our website under Parents > Resources > Parent Forms & Notices. https://www.susq.k12.pa.us/Page/818

Updated mask requirement released by the Pennsylvania Departments of Education and Health

The Pennsylvania Department of Education in cooperation with the Department of Health announced yesterday, the requirement of all students to wear face coverings at all times, while in school. This is an update from the prior recommendation, in that, the requirement extends to instances when students and staff are able to maintain an appropriate six-foot social distance. The update is based on the American Academy of Pediatrics’ (AAP) updated guidance strongly recommending children age two and older should wear face coverings at all times to help mitigate the spread of the COVID-19 virus.

Susquenita School District will keep you posted on any new developments as they unfold. This is just the most recent in what feels like daily twists and turns associated with COVID-19.

post_text: Taxpayer Flexibility: Senate Bill 1125, providing property tax payment relief, has passed. What this means…taxpayers will now have the discount extended 30 days (to September 30th) and penalty eliminated through December 31, 2020. Installment dates to remain the same. This ruling comes after the district’s tax distribution deadline and therefore the language was not included in the tax bills. We are hopeful this allows flexibility to our taxpayers who may have felt the financial burden in the wake of COVID-19.

The Susquenita School District will be closed tomorrow, Wednesday, October 23, 2019. The District experienced a major water leak yesterday afternoon which disrupted drinking water to the entire campus. The leak was repaired yesterday, and water testing was completed yesterday evening. All results indicated that the drinking water was within acceptable limits, and thus, the District held school this morning. The Susquenita School District was contacted at 1:39 PM today by the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (DEP), informing us that because water service was interrupted to the entire campus, we must undergo a 72 hour “Boil Water Notice,” and do testing through Thursday.

As a result of this late notice we will be closing school tomorrow while we make preparations and arrangements to have bottled water on campus for all students and staff, as well as water for food preparation on Thursday. We anticipate resuming normal school operations Thursday, October 24, 2019. We will be posting the latest information on the Susquenita School District website.

Here's What You Need to Know About the Total Solar Eclipse

On Monday, August 21st, Americans are set to witness an astronomical event that hasn’t happened since 1918. A solar eclipse is when the moon passes between the earth and the sun. From the west to east coast, the sun will go black for two minutes.

Susquenita School District is providing a quick resource for families to reference as you talk about the solar eclipse with your children: Here's What You Need to Know About the Total Solar Eclipse - https://www.susq.k12.pa.us/cms/lib/PA02209671/Centricity/Domain/4/Total%20Solar%20Eclipse%20.pdf

We hope you find it beneficial when discussing the event and related safety precautions.
